user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_rmfs:
```c
int32 OS_rmfs(const char *devname)
{
    int32             return_code;
    OS_object_token_t token;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_PATHNAME(devname);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetByName(OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, devname, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /*
         * NOTE: It is likely that if the file system is mounted,
         * this call to stop the volume will fail.
         *
         * It would be prudent to first check the flags to ensure that
         * the filesystem is unmounted first, but this would break
         * compatibility with the existing unit tests.
         */
        return_code = OS_FileSysStopVolume_Impl(&token);

        /* Free the entry in the master table  */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(return_code, &token);
    }
    else
    {
        return_code = OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_rmfs:
#define OS_CHECK_PATHNAME(str) OS_CHECK_STRING(str,OS_MAX_PATH_LEN,OS_FS_ERR_PATH_TOO_LONG)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetByName(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, const char *name, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(lock_mode, idtype, OS_ObjectNameMatch, (void *)name, token);
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t MatchFunc, void *arg,
                             OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdFindNextMatch(MatchFunc, arg, token);

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "lock_mode" parameter.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }
    else
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
OS_CHECK_PATHNAME(devname);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The macro expands to OS_CHECK_STRING(devname, ...). There is no evidence in the provided code that the macro assigns to the parameter variable or changes the pointer value; it only performs checks (e.g. NULL/length). devname is declared const char * so typical checks read the pointed-to data without modifying the pointer. A violation would occur if OS_CHECK_STRING assigned to its 'str' parameter (e.g. str = ...;) or cast away const and modified the characters via *str, which would modify the function parameter/pointee in contravention of Rule 17.8.
